Polyhedron-like Co-embedded carbon catalyst derived from ZIF-67 by surface confinement pyrolysis strategy for upgrading of ethyl levulinate to γ-valerolactone Yingying Dong Data curation Writing – original draft Wenxiu Li Investigation Data curation Liguo Ma Data curation Investigation Qingqing Zhu Writing – review & editing Xiangjin Kong Supervision Writing – review & editing Project administration ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory / Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Energy Storage & Novel Cell Technology, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng, Shandong 252000, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory / Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Energy Storage & Novel Cell Technology Liaocheng University Liaocheng Shandong 252000 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong Provincial Key Laboratory / Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Energy Storage & Novel Cell Technology, Liaocheng University, Liaocheng, Shandong 252000, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Polyhedron-like Co-embedded carbon catalyst was constructed through a P123-assisted surface-confinement pyrolysis strategy using ZIF-67 as precursor in the present studies. The introduction of P123 resulted in a homogeneously distributed hierarchical pore structure of the catalyst, modulated the composition of different valence Co species and limited the agglomeration of cobalt nanoparticles, which improves the hydrogenation and dehydration ability of the catalyst, and thus endow it robust activity and long-term durability in conversion of ethyl levulinate to γ-valerolactone (Yield ≥98%, well stability for no less than 7 runs). The present work may supply a novel strategy for synthesis of polyhedron-like carbon materials for the transformation of biomass-plate molecular in the range hydrogenation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Surface confinement pyrolysis strategy Polyhedron-like Co-embedded carbon catalyst γ-valerolactone Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the shift in the current chemical economy toward increased utilization of renewable raw materials, the upgrading of biomass has become an important topic [1,2]. Biomass is considered to be the “zero-carbon energy source “among many emerging renewable resources [3,4]. Biomass or biomass platform compounds can be converted into high value-added biofuels and chemicals through chemical technologies [5–7]. As one of the biomass-based chemicals, γ-valerolactone (GVL) has high calorific value and high energy density, which can be used not only as a precursor for the production of gasoline and diesel fuels but also as an intermediate to synthesize a variety of valuable chemicals [8–11]. In the context of carbon neutralization, the green synthesis of GVL from bio-based levulinic acid (derivatives) was undoubtedly of great economic, environmental and social significance. So far, although the synthesis of GVL from levulinic acid (derivatives) has been achieved on noble or non-noble metal catalysts, non-noble metal catalysts have attracted the attention of scientific researchers due to their lower cost. In this case, catalysts based on Co, Ni and Cu are often developed [12–15]. However, these catalysts usually show poor activity and stability. To promote the catalytic performance of these catalysts, confining the metal component into heteroatom-doped carbon material was proved to be a feasible strategy [16–18]. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) particularly ZIF-67 represents one of the promising precursors for the preparation of these carbon composite catalysts, since most carbon atoms of ZIF-67 could maintained during the pyrolysis process in inert gas and the cobalt nodes would be reduced in situ at high temperature [19–22]. However, the porosity of framework carbon is easily collapsed during high temperature carbonized/pyrolysis process, leads to a decrease in porosity and agglomeration of metal components, which can limit the mass transport and the use of active sites. In view of this, it is highly desirable to find a balanced strategy to achieve a Co-embedded carbon catalyst with high metal species dispersion and well porous structures for the synthesis of GVL. Recently, etching, regrowth, mSiO2 hard template methods etc. have been developed to construct 3D Co@N-doped carbon catalyst from ZIF-67. Among these methods, mSiO2 hard template method has become a widely used method because of its induced rigid interface effect which can effectively limits the collapse of the precursor [23]. However, the resulting mSiO2 shell was difficult to remove and is more likely to cause collapse of the material structure. By using the strong interactions between surfactants and nanocrystal particles in solution phase, PVP, polymerized dopamine, phenolic resin and so on, have been applied for covering onto the ZIFs nanocrystals to assist the preparation of hierarchical N-doped carbon materials [24–26]. Unfortunately, most of these catalysts are used in electrocatalytic reactions, and there are few reports on their application in the conversion of biomass platform molecules based on hydrogenation-dehydration mechanism. Although these methods can avoid the problem of difficult removal of mSiO2 shell, it is still a subject worthy of study to obtain efficient catalyst for the transformation of levulinic acid (derivatives) to GVL by adjusting the preparation method of the catalyst. Here, an P123-assisted surface-confinement strategy was developed for preparing 3D Co@pC (porous N-doped carbon) catalysts [27,28]. It was found that the rapid aggregation in the internal of ZIF-67 could be prevent during the high-temperature due to the confinement role of P123, and resulting in the obtained Co@pC catalyst possess a 3D porous structure, and optimum metal composition, which may endow the catalyst better activity and stability. As far as we know, this strategy has not yet been applied to fabricate ZIFs derived Co@pC catalyst for conversion of biomass platform molecule in the range of hydrogenation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Co@pC catalyst ZIF-67 was synthesized according to previous studies [21], and the detailed procedures for the introduction of P123 to ZIF-67 (Be named ZIFs/P123) were listed in the support material (ESI). The main procedure for the fabrication of ZIFs derived catalyst was listed in Scheme 1 . In general, 2.0 g ZIFs/P123 was put in a tubular furnace, and the temperature is raised to 350 °C at a rate of 2 °C/min and hold for 2 h in an N2 atmosphere, and then the temperature is raised to an 800 °C at a rate of 2 °C/min and hold for 3 h to obtain the Co@pC-800 (800 represent the pyrolysis temperature). In order to conduct a comparative experiment, ZIF-800 (without P123 template) was prepared followed basically the same procedure as that of Co@pC-800. 2.2 Catalytic tests Ethyl levulinate (EL) can be prepared by esterification of levulinic acid and alcoholysis of furfuryl alcohol. Compared with levulinic acid, its source is more abundant. Therefore, in the present studies ethyl levulinate was used as the initial material for the synthesis of GVL. In a typical experiment, 0.05 g catalyst, 5 mL 1,4-dioxane, and 0.5 mL EL were add to the autoclave. Then it was sealed, and replaced the air by H2. Subsequently, it was pressurized with H2 to 2.0 MPa. Under the stirring of 400 rpm, lowly raising temperature of reaction system to 200 °C, and the reaction was quenched quickly after the temperature was maintained for 6 h. The liquid reaction product was analyzed by GC-MS (Agilent Technologies 7890B-5977A). The conversion and selectivity were calculated as follows: Conversion ( % ) = Mole of EL converted ( mol ) Mole of EL fed ( mol ) × 100 Selectivity ( % ) = Mole of GVL producted ( mol ) Mole of EL converted ( mol ) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization All samples showed H4-type isotherms and obvious hysteresis loops (Fig. 1 ), which indicated the mesoporous structure of the catalyst [29,30]. The pore structure of the Co@ pC-800 deteriorates significantly as the pyrolysis temperature increases (Table 1 ), which can be attributed to the higher temperature leading to collapse of the catalyst structure. However, the SBET, pore volume and average pore diameter of Co@ pC-800 are significantly higher than that of ZIF-800, which may be due to the existence of P123 layers limits the collapse of ZIF-67 rhombic dodecahedra structure Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 3 , all Co@pC exhibits three typical peaks in 468 cm−1, 509 cm−1, 675 cm−1, respectively corresponding to the Eg, F2g(2), A1g vibration mode of Co3O4 [31,32]. These peaks gradually become smaller with the rise of pyrolysis temperature, indicating that higher temperature is conducive to in-situ reduction of Coδ+. No similar peak was observed for ZIF-800, which indicated that the coating of surfactant film on ZIF-67 catalyst can restrict the in-situ reduction process. The value of ID/IG decreased with the increase of pyrolysis temperatures, suggesting a gradual increase both in the degree of defects and graphitization. The above results are well consistent with the XRD patterns. Compared with Co@pC-800, ZIF-800 has higher ID/IG ratio, indicating that the addition of P123 was beneficial to increase the graphitization degree of catalyst. In general, the graphitized structure is helpful for electronic conductivity and corrosion resistance during catalysis, thus improving their catalytic performance and durability [24]. Fig. 4 depicted the XRD spectra of these catalysts. The peak of 26° can be assigned to a typical C (002) interlayer of graphite-type carbon sheets [33], while the diffraction peaks observed at 44.2°, 51.5°, and 75.9° correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) lattice planes of Co0 (PDF#. 15-0806), respectively. With the pyrolysis temperature of precursor rising from 700 to 900 °C, the peak intensity of Co (111) is enhanced and the peak shape is gradually sharpened, indicating that the crystallinity of Co NPs gradually increases. Compared with ZIF-800, the (002) plane diffraction peak of C of Co@pC-800 is more obvious, indicating that the addition of P123 increases the degree of graphitization of carbon. This conclusion was consistent with Raman characterization results. SEM images (Fig. 5 a and b) shows that the ZIF-67 synthesized in the present studies is uniform in size and regular in shapes. ZIFs/P123 (Fig. 5d and e) possesses a similar dodecahedron configuration with that of ZIF-67 (Fig. 5a,b), and P123-shell is visible in the surface of ZIF-67. Compared with the pristine ZIF-67 (Fig. 5a,b), ZIF-800 (Fig. 5c, the catalyst after pyrolysis) shows certain volume shrinkage, and some of the ZIF-67 crystals fused together to form large particles. By comparison, Co@pC-800 almost maintains the dodecahedron configuration of the precursor (Fig. 5f). The Elemental mapping (Fig. S1) results showed that C, N, O and Co elements are uniformly present on the polyhedron-like particle. The HR-TEM image of Co@pC-800 (Fig. S1) proved that the Co particles were embedded in carbon matrices and the lattice fringes with an inter-planar distance of 0.205, 0.465 and 0.338 nm correspond to the Co (111) plane, Co3O4 (111) and C (002), respectively. TEM (Fig. 5i and h) displayed that the cobalt nanoparticles in Co@pC-800 had a smaller diameter than that of ZIF-800. This indicates that the strategy of P123-assisted surface confinement pyrolysis strategy can effectively suppress the growth of Co particle [34]. The acid property of the catalyst has a great influence on the conversion reaction of biomass platforms [35], so the NH3-TPD spectrums of the catalyst are depicted in Fig. 6 . It can be seen that these catalysts all have two obvious weak acid and medium strong acid site desorption peak. Table S1 shows that acidic capacity on these catalysts varies inversely with the pyrolysis temperature, indicating that the increase of the pyrolysis temperature was favorable for in-situ reduction of Coδ+ species, thereby reducing the Lewis acidic capacity of the catalyst. This is consistent with the previous Raman results. By comparison, whether weak acid sites or strong acid sites, Co@pC-800 was more than ZIF-800, indicating that due to the existence of P123 layer, the Coδ+ are more difficult to be reduced in the in-situ pyrolysis process. XPS survey spectrum shows peaks of C1s, N1s, O1s and Co 2p (Fig. S2). The results indicated that Cospecies has been incorporated into the N doped carbon materials. The Co 2p 3/2 spectrum of these Co based catalyst could be resolved to four peaks at 778.3, 780.4, 782.9, and 786.3 eV, corresponding to Co0, Co3+, Co2+and the satellite peak of Co-O (Fig. 7 and Table S1). As shown in Table S2, with the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the proportion of elemental Co increased significantly, while the content of oxidized Co decreased significantly. Table S2 also shows that with the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the content of metal Co on the catalyst increased slightly, and the introduction of P123 did not cause a significant change in the content of metallic Co on the catalyst. Therefore, The XPS characterization results is consistent with the previous NH3-TPD and Raman characterization results, that is, higher temperature is conducive to the in-situ reduction of metal ions in the catalyst precursor. Compared with Co@pC-800, ZIF-800 displays a higher Coδ+ species content, indicating that the P123 plays an obvious role in the restricted pyrolytic reduction of ZIF-67 precursor. 3.2 The catalytic performance As shown in Table 2 , the reaction cannot proceed without the catalyst, when ZIF-800 was used as the catalyst, the conversion of EL was 98% and the selectivity of GVL reached 78%, with ethyl 4-hydroxypentanoate (4-HPE) as the main by-product and a amount of 4-pentanediol (1,4-PDO) and 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) by-product (Fig. S3). In view of these results, the preliminary reaction route was speculated and listed in Scheme 2 [36,37]. Route a show that EL firstly produces 4‑hydroxy-pentanoic by hydrogenation of the carbonyl, which is unstable during the reaction and further generation of GVL through intramolecular transesterification. Route b is the hydrogenation of the ester carbonyl to generate the intermediate product 4-HPE, followed by the cyclization and dehydration to get GVL over the acidic active sites (Coδ+). GVL is further hydrogenated to form over-hydrogenated product 1,4-PDO and 2-MTHF over the hydrogenation active sites (Co0). According to the GC-MS analysis results discussed above, 4-HPE was found in the reaction product. Therefore, the transformation of EL to GVL over the present catalyst probably followed the reaction pathway as in shown in route b. The performance of Co@pC-800 was greatly improved by coating P123 with the catalyst precursor, EL could be completely converted, the formation of 4-HPE was greatly limited, and the selectivity of GVL could reach 97% (Table 2 entry 3). These results were consistent with the catalyst characterization results, that is, compared with ZIF-800, the better dispersion of Co species on Co@pC-800 helps to improve its hydrogenation activity, and its stronger acidity derived from the high content of Coδ+ (Table S2) helps to promote the cyclization of 4-HPE to generate GVL. The activity of Co@pC-700 (Table 2 entry 4) was lower than Co@pC-800. It is speculated that the reduction of Coδ+was not thorough enough at lower pyrolysis temperature. So, the content of cobalt in the oxidation state is high, so there are fewer hydrogenation active sites (Table S1 and 2). Co@pC-900 only gives an EL conversion of 68% and a GVL selectivity of 75% (entry 5). It is speculated that there are two reasons: On the one hand, due to the excessive pyrolysis temperature, the collapse of frame structure, the specific surface area was reduced and a part of the pores were blocked. During the reaction, the substrate and the active site are not fully contacted, and the reaction is not sufficient, resulting in a low conversion of EL. In addition, due to the high pyrolysis temperature, increase the surface free energy of metal nanoparticles, and the nanoparticles tend to reduce the surface area, so they are easy to agglomerate together, which reduces the catalytic activity. These results were consistent with the previous characterization results, which further confirms that metallic Co was the main active center of hydrogenation, and Coδ+ (Co2+, Co3+) was the acidic center. As shown in Scheme 2 (Route B), the upgrading of EL to GVL mainly includes two reaction steps of hydrogenation of raw materials and dehydration and cyclization of intermediate product. Obviously, the hydrogenation step is mainly realized by metal active sites, while dehydration mainly occurs in acid catalytic active sites. Combined with the catalyst characterization and catalytic performance test results of these catalysts. It can be summed up that the excellent catalytic performance of Co@pC-800 was the result of the synergistic effect of better metal dispersion and appropriate acidic sites. The effect of reaction conditions was evaluated. As shown in Fig. 8 , when the reaction was performed at 0.5 MPa of H2 pressures, only 25% of EL conversion, and 80% GVL selectivity were obtained. When increasing the H2 pressure to 1 MPa, the conversion of EL increased to 88%, while the selectivity of GVL increased only 9% along with a great increase in formation of 4-HPE. When the pressure was up to 2 MPa, conversion of EL and selectivity to GVL reached to 100% and 97%. When the pressure was further increased to 2.5 MPa, it was found that the conversion was still 100%, while the selectivity of GVL reduced by 5% due to the formation of excessive hydrogenation byproducts such as 1,4-PDO and 2-MTHF. The influence of reaction temperatures is listed in Fig. 9 . As the temperature increases, the catalytic activity also increases gradually. The conversion of EL reached 100% at 200 °C, and remained unchanged even if the temperature was further increased, while the selectivity first increased and then decreased, indicating that over high temperature will bring byproducts and reduce the selectivity. The optimal reaction pressure and temperature were determined to be 2 MPa and 200 °C. To have a further understanding of the reaction pathway, the time-conversion curves and product distributions were depicted in Fig. 10 . In the first 2 h, the conversion of EL was 33%, with GVL accounting for 18.8% and 4-HPE accounting for 14.2%, followed by a slight decrease in formation of 4-HPE. When the reaction time was 5 h, almost no 4-HPE could be detected. It is worth noting that there is only 4-HPE and no other intermediate product in the above process. These results further confirmed the reaction pathway as listed in the Scheme 2. That is to say, 4-HPE was firstly formed in the hydrogenation active site of the catalyst by EL, and then GVL is further formed under the action of the acidic sites. The well activity of Co@pC-800 was due to the high dispersion of metal active sites and the synergistic effect of appropriate acidic sites. The activity of Co@pC-800 was compared with the results reported in the literatures; it was found that the Co@pC-800 catalyst developed in this study is more active than most of the other representative catalysts in the literatures (Table S3). 3.3 Reusability performance of Co@pC-800 Since the conversion of EL on Co@pC-800 reached 100% under the optimal conditions, in order to better compare the stability of the catalyst, the stability test was carried out under a low conversion condition (Fig. 11 ). The activity of the catalyst remained almost unchanged during 7 consecutive cycles, even if the catalyst was used for 10 times, the selectivity of GVL was still more than 80%. The spent catalyst has similar XRD pattern with the fresh one, indicating that the structure of the catalyst has not changed even after 10 cycles (Fig. S4). The stability of the catalyst structure was further proved by the existence of H4-type hysteresis loop and less change of adsorption amount in the N2 adsorption-desorption curve of the spent catalyst (Fig. S5). The results of ICP-AES analysis showed that the content of Co on the spent catalyst was basically the same as that on the fresh one, and no Co was detected in the solution. So, the slight drop in the conversion of EL yield after 7 cycles was probably due to the mass loss of the catalyst in each collection-and-run cycle. These results confirmed that the catalyst not only has good activity, but also has good stability, and these results further proves that the strategy of using surfactant limited domain to construct catalyst is feasible, so it has well promotion prospect. 4 Conclusion A P123 assisted-confinement strategy has been proposed for construction of ZIFs-derived Co@N-doped carbon catalyst. The obtained Co@pC-800 catalyst has a well-balanced porous structure and composition, which makes it a well catalyst for hydrogenation of EL to GVL. The P123-assisted strategy may provide new a new research idea to prepare ZIFs-derived porous carbon materials for the upgrading of biomass molecules in the range of hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Polyhedron-like Co-embedded carbon catalyst was constructed through a P123-assisted surface-confinement pyrolysis strategy using ZIF-67 as precursor in the present studies. The introduction of P123 resulted in a homogeneously distributed hierarchical pore structure of the catalyst, modulated the composition of different valence Co species and limited the agglomeration of cobalt nanoparticles, which improves the hydrogenation and dehydration ability of the catalyst, and thus endow it robust activity and long-term durability in conversion of ethyl levulinate to γ-valerolactone (Yield ≥98%, well stability for no less than 7 runs). The present work may supply a novel strategy for synthesis of polyhedron-like carbon materials for the transformation of biomass-plate molecular in the range hydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Polyhedron-like Co-embedded carbon catalyst derived from ZIF-67 by surface confinement pyrolysis strategy for upgrading of ethyl levulinate to γ-valerolactone
